comments.content: Yes, Port 80 is open. would lead me to believe network interception is the only logical choice

discussion.content: Port 80 is open. Should be pretty easy to intercept network traffic.

Selected Answer: C
BEST attempt given what we know.

comments.content:
The thing I see going wrong is the security officer checking some kind of list to confirm whether they are expecting a contractor for maintenance... and obviously seeing that no one is expected. We just don't know what their routine is for this scenario (neither does the pentester). And once the pentester has made that much of a scene and had a face-to-face interaction, it would be more difficult to go unnoticed another way.

Option C provides the best attempt given what we do know.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
it has to be

questions.question_text: A penetration tester is given an assignment to gain physical access to a secure facility with perimeter cameras. The secure facility does not accept visitors, and entry is available only through a door protected by an RFID key and a guard stationed inside the door. Which of the following would be BEST for the penetration tester to attempt?

choices.A: Gain entry into the building by posing as a contractor who is performing routine building maintenance.
choices.B: Tailgate into the facility with an employee who has a valid RFID badge to enter.
choices.C: Duplicate an employee's RFID badge and use an IR camera to see when the guard leaves the post.
choices.D: Look for an open window that can be used to gain unauthorized entry into the facility.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is trying to identify the source of a recent data loss incident. The analyst has reviewed all the logs for the time surrounding the incident and identified all the assets on the network at the time of the data loss. The analyst suspects the key to finding the source was obfuscated in an application. Which of the following tools should the analyst use NEXT?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Static Code analysis is the correct answer!
Used to reverse heavily obfuscated code.

Mabye: D. Static code analysis?
Question states: "the source was obfuscated" - that does not mean that there is no source code available.

Just because I didn't know what process explorer was.

"What is Process Explorer?
Process Explorer is part of the Sysinternals suite (acquired by Microsoft) created by Mark Russinovich. It is like Windows Task Manager but offers many more features."
https://www.thecybersecurityexpert.com/incident-response-using-process-explorer-look-malware/
I would be suspicious with PID 4 and PID 513

questions.question_text: Following the most recent patch deployment, a security engineer receives reports that the ERP application is no longer accessible. The security engineer reviews the situation and determines a critical security patch that was applied to the ERP server is the cause. The patch is subsequently backed out. Which of the following security controls would be BEST to implement to mitigate the threat caused by the missing patch?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
this is test
mitigate the threat caused by missing patch. the question is like if no patch how to protect the server?-->HIPS
Who's to say that a future untested patch doesn't break your HIPS. I would say you need to test patches before you start swapping software.

questions.answer_description:
A Host Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS) is newer than a HIDS, with the main difference being that a HIPS can take action toward mitigating a detected threat.
Reference:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/host-intrusion-prevention-system
